summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from November 9, 2020, summarizing national and international news relevant to the FBI and law enforcement. It covers election security, protests, criminal investigations, counter-terrorism, cyber threats, and other Washington news. The document is a daily intelligence briefing for FBI leadership, not directly related to the Epstein case.

persons.name: Carol Cratty
persons.context: Quoted in the briefing regarding election security, stating the FBI had nothing new to add to previous statements about foreign interference in mail ballots.

persons.name: Laura Eimiller
persons.context: Quoted regarding an LAPD custody case involving a man who threatened a mass shooting if Biden won the election.

persons.name: Angelo DeFeao
persons.context: Authored an affidavit in the case against Jason Solomon Stokes, who was arrested for allegedly planning an attack on Fort Campbell.

persons.name: David M. DeVillers
persons.context: Announced the upheld conviction of Laith Waleed Alebbini for attempting to join ISIS.

persons.name: Eric B. Smith
persons.context: Commented on a 'grandparent scam' case, emphasizing the need to protect the elderly population.

persons.name: Omer Meisel
persons.role: Acting FBI Special Agent in Charge
persons.context: Commented on a charity fraud case in California, calling the theft of donations disheartening.

persons.name: Thomas F. Relford
persons.context: Named in a news release regarding the arrest of Thomas Love Jr. for distributing child pornography.

persons.name: James Jewell
persons.context: Named in an announcement regarding the sentencing of DeGregory Deon Lee for armed robbery.

persons.name: Christopher Wray
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of Steve Bannon's controversial remarks, where Bannon suggested putting his and Dr. Fauci's 'heads on pikes.'

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Was permanently banned from Twitter after urging President Trump to put Dr. Fauci and FBI Director Wray's 'heads on pikes.' His lawyer subsequently quit his fraud case.

persons.name: William Burck
persons.context: Lawyer for Steve Bannon who quit defending him in a federal fraud case after Bannon's inflammatory comments.

events.title: FBI Daily News Briefing
events.description: The FBI Public Affairs Office distributes its daily news briefing covering leading news, protests, counter-terrorism, criminal investigations, and other topics relevant to law enforcement.

events.title: Twitter bans Steve Bannon
events.description: Twitter permanently suspended Steve Bannon's account after he posted a video urging President Trump to demote Dr. Anthony Fauci and fire FBI Director Christopher Wray, adding he'd put their 'heads on pikes.'

events.title: Bannon's lawyer quits fraud case
events.description: Attorney William Burck withdrew from defending Steve Bannon in a federal fraud case a day after Bannon's inflammatory comments about Dr. Fauci and FBI Director Wray.

keyFacts: This document is an FBI internal news briefing, not a legal document pertaining to the Epstein case.
The briefing covers a wide range of law enforcement and national security topics from November 2020, including election security, protests, and various criminal investigations.
It mentions FBI Director Christopher Wray in the context of controversial remarks made by Steve Bannon.
The document illustrates the FBI's role in monitoring domestic threats, cybercrime, and terrorism during a politically volatile period.
No individuals or events directly related to Jeffrey Epstein, Ghislaine Maxwell, or associated investigations are mentioned in this excerpt.
